DOCNAME: CASE OF OKLEŠEN AND POKOPALIŠKO POGREBNE STORITVE LEOPOLD OKLEŠEN S.P. v. SLOVENIA
JUDGES: Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ineta Ziemele;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in ORG . The second applicant is a private enterprise called FAC and ORG s.p . ( NORP pogrebne storitve PERSON . ) located in ORG .

CARDINAL . The second applicant , which was owned , legally represented and run by the first applicant , had held a valid licence issued by ORG ( obrtno dovoljenje ) for the provision of funerals , landscaping and maintenance of exterior surfaces ( zunanja ureditev ) since DATE . The licence confirmed that the second applicant was in compliance with section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The second applicant used to provide all funeral services in ORG municipality , including preparing and transporting remains , obtaining the necessary documents , arranging cremations , selling funeral items ( coffins , funeral wreaths , flowers and so on ) and organising ceremonies . It appears that funerals represented an important , if not the main , part of the activities of the second applicant .

CARDINAL . In DATE a Decree on the provision of public utility as regards cemetery and funeral activities , management of cemeteries and funeral ceremonies in GPE ( “ the DATE Decree ” , see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) came into force . Subsequently , ORG ( ORG , “ KNM ” ) was entrusted with the provision of such services in the municipality 's area .

CARDINAL . According to ORG 's website ( http://www.komunala-nm.si/ , consulted on DATE ) , ORG provided services concerning , inter alia , digging and organising graves , obtaining documents concerning the deceased , preparation and storage of remains , funeral home leasing , organisation and performance of funeral ceremonies and services and transportation of remains .

CARDINAL . By a letter of DATE , ORG warned the second applicant to comply with DATE Decree . This implied , according to ORG , that “ all activities relating to those deceased ( ... ) who are to be buried in cemeteries managed by ORG should be carried out solely by ORG ! ”

CARDINAL . On DATE , further to the second applicant 's request , ORG explained that the second applicant was not eligible to provide funeral services because of the restrictions set out in DATE Decree , the DATE LAW and the Cemetery and Funeral Services and LAW ( “ the DATE FAC ” ) . The GPE further stated that the ORG decision no . U - I-CARDINAL/CARDINAL had confirmed that funerals should be a mandatory public utility ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant submitted a request to ORG for a review of the constitutionality and legality ( pobuda za oceno ustavnosti in zakonitosti ) of the CARDINAL Decree , in particular sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL . While section CARDINAL provided , inter alia , that funerals should be provided by a public utility , section CARDINAL established that a provider of a public utility , namely a public - law enterprise , should be contacted in the event of a death and should be responsible for transport of the remains .

CARDINAL . NORP In its request , the second applicant argued that funeral provision should be in the free market , and requested ORG to issue an injunction against DATE Decree . The second applicant further stated that , following the adoption of DATE Decree , ORG had obtained a monopoly in this field and did not allow it to transport remains to cemeteries . It submitted that the DATE Decree had been introduced with the intention of closing down its successful business .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the second applicant 's request , referring to its earlier decision no . U - I-CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) finding that section CARDINAL of the DATE Cemetery and Funeral Act was in conformity with the LAW . The above - mentioned provision read together with section DATE of the DATE LAW determined that the funeral services belonged to the mandatory public utilities . These rules were binding on the GPE , which was required to implement them .

CARDINAL . According to the applicants , as a result of the above situation the second applicant has been unable to provide the core funeral services since the implementation of the DATE Decree and has lost a large proportion of the clientele due to the CARDINAL Decree 's restrictions .

CARDINAL . The second applicant continued to operate until DATE . For illustration of the effects of the DATE Decree 's restrictions on the applicants ' earnings , it would appear from the first 's applicant 's tax forms concerning the second applicant 's activity , that his taxable income was calculated as follows : in DATE , it was MONEY ( ORG ) , in DATE it was ORG CARDINAL , in DATE it was LAW and in DATE it was CARDINAL . After the implementation of the CARDINAL Decree , his taxable income was approximately ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL in DATE , ORG CARDINAL in DATE and ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant was removed from the NORP register of enterprises . The first applicant retired in DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW ( PERSON , ORG no . CARDINAL ) , provide as follows :
“ The right to private property and inheritance shall be guaranteed . ”

“ Free economic initiative shall be guaranteed . PERSON The conditions for establishing commercial organisations shall be established by law . Commercial activities may not be pursued in a manner contrary to the public interest . CARDINAL Unfair competition practices and practices which restrict competition in a manner contrary to the law are prohibited . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW ( Zakon o ustavnem sodišču , ORG no . CARDINAL ) , which concern the review of constitutionality and legality , were at the relevant time as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Anyone who demonstrates a legal interest may submit a request for a procedure to be initiated for a review of the constitutionality or legality of regulations or general acts issued for the exercise of public authority .

( CARDINAL ) A legal interest is deemed to be demonstrated if a regulation or general act issued for the exercise of public authority whose review has been requested by the petitioner directly interferes with his rights , legal interests , or legal position . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG rejects a request if the procedural conditions ... have not been fulfilled .
( CARDINAL ) ORG dismisses a request if it is manifestly unfounded or if it can not be expected that an important legal question will be resolved .
( CARDINAL ) ORG decides by an order to accept or dismiss a request by a majority vote of judges present . The order to dismiss a request must include a statement of reasons .

( CARDINAL ) If ORG accepts a request , it may immediately proceed to decide on the merits of the case if the factual situation has been clarified and if during consideration of the request the opposing party has been given the opportunity to make statements . ”

“ In deciding on the constitutionality and legality of a regulation or general act issued for the exercise of public authority , ORG is not bound by the production of a request . ORG may also review the constitutionality and legality of other provisions of the same or another regulation or general act issued for the exercise of public authority for which a review of constitutionality or legality has not been proposed , if such provisions are mutually related or if this is necessary to resolve the case . ”

( CARDINAL ) ORG quashes regulations or general acts issued for the exercise of public authority that are unconstitutional or unlawful when it determines that it is necessary to remedy harmful consequences arising from such unconstitutionality or unlawfulness . Quashing has retroactive effect .

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any person who suffers harmful consequences due to a regulation or general act issued for the exercise of public authority which has been quashed is entitled to request that such consequences be remedied .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Cemetery and Funeral Act , which was adopted in DATE and continued to be in force after the independence of GPE ( Zakon o pokopališki in pogrebni dejavnosti ter o urejanju pokopališč , ORG of GPE no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , provides that cemetery and funeral services , as well as the running of cemeteries , correspond to “ municipal activities of special social importance ” ( komunalna dejavnost posebnega družbenega pomena ) . According to section CARDINAL , transport of the deceased was to be provided by a specially designed vehicle of a local public organisation ( komunalne organizacije ) or the local community ( krajevne skupnosti ) .

CARDINAL . The DATE LAW ( Zakon o gospodarskih javnih službah , ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , entered into force on DATE ) provides in section CARDINAL that mandatory public utilities should be established by law . Local decrees should regulate the way the local public utilities operate . Section CARDINAL provides that public utilities may be ensured through the form of a public - law enterprise ( javno podjetje ) , or through concessions ( koncesija ) granted to private enterprises .

CARDINAL . Finally , section DATE provides that until the introduction of legislation establishing specific public utilities , “ activities of special social importance ” should be deemed to be public utilities .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Obrtni zakon , Official Gazette no . CARDINAL ) provides the following conditions under which a licence may be issued by ORG :
“ ( CARDINAL ) The conditions for obtaining a licence to provide a crafts service are as follows :
– title of master craftsman ,
– proof of fulfilment of the minimum requirements prescribed for providing a certain service .
( CARDINAL ) The conditions for obtaining a craft licence to provide a service which is similar to a crafts service are ...
( CARDINAL ) The minimum requirements prescribed for providing a certain service from the preceding paragraphs are as follows :
– minimum technical and other conditions relating to the space where the service is provided , land and other exterior surface , facilities and equipment ,
– minimum sanitary and health conditions relating to the space where the service is provided , land and other exterior surface , facilities , equipment and the people who work in the workplace
– minimum conditions relating to the exterior surface ( land and other exterior surface ) . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted a Decree on the provision of public utilities ( “ the DATE Decree ” , Official Gazette CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , which listed funeral services as optional public utility . This Decree was amended on DATE ( “ the DATE LAW , Official Gazette CARDINAL ) . The latter listed funeral and cemetery services among the mandatory public utilities and stipulated that with respect to the cemeteries provided under special decree these services should be provided by a public - law enterprise . On DATE ORG adopted a new Decree on the provision of public utilities ( “ the DATE Decree ” , Official Gazette CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , which quashed the previous decree and its amendment . It also listed cemetery and funeral services as mandatory public utilities and stated that a special municipal decree should determine the exact structure by means of which each of the listed public utilities should be provided . On DATE Decree was amended ( “ the DATE Amendment ” , ORG CARDINAL ) , to include a provision stating that “ public utilities .... funeral and cemetery services , which should be carried out by a public - law enterprise according to specific decrees , shall be provided by ORG ” . LAW also stated that “ provided that a particular public service is not entirely provided by ORG , a part of that service can be carried out by another entity on the basis of a contract signed with ORG ... ”

CARDINAL . According to LAW ( Official Gazette no . CARDINAL , entered into force in DATE ) , cemetery and funeral services , management of cemeteries and funeral ceremonies in GPE should be provided by a mandatory public utility in the form of a public - law enterprise ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . The Decree lists CARDINAL cemeteries situated within the ORG municipal area ; it applies to all of them .
Section CARDINAL of the Decree provides :
“ Funerals are normally conducted outside cemeteries and include in particular the following :
- obtaining the required documents ;
- preparation of the body and transport of the remains ;
- renting graves and managing the registry of cemeteries ;
- providing an emergency funeral service ;
- providing other services established by the law or this decree . ”

CARDINAL . LAW of the DATE Decree provides that the relatives and the relevant institutions should report the death of a person to the provider of a mandatory public utility . The remains can be taken from a hospital or a retirement home only by the provider of a mandatory public utility . The latter should take the remains from the person or institution concerned and take them to a place specifically designated for this purpose ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a decision in a case brought by a private funeral provider , P. , from GPE na GPE municipality . The court found that section CARDINAL of the DATE Cemetery and Funeral Act was not in conflict with LAW , and neither was the impugned municipality decree , which established funeral services as a local public utility . ORG noted that , since no new act had been adopted in this area , funeral and cemetery services were deemed to be public utility on the basis of section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW read together with LAW Cemetery and Funeral Act .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court found that the restrictions resulting from the system whereby cemetery and funeral services must be provided as a public utility were justified by the public interest . In addition , the court accepted the municipality 's argument that for ethical , health and sanitary and hygiene reasons funerals could not be provided in the free market . Finally , ORG took into consideration the fact that the impugned regulation was of a transitional nature pending the adoption of a specific law , and found that the duration of this situation had not yet contravened the principle of the rule of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( GPE za varstvo konkurence – “ the Competition Office ” ) issued a decision declaring lack of jurisdiction to deal with the complaint lodged by the private funeral services provider PERSON latter argued that the municipal enterprise authorised to provide funeral services on the basis of the municipal decree refused to accept at the cemetery remains transported by it .

CARDINAL . ORG declared lack of jurisdiction to deal with the complaint , since the impugned decree concerned the ORG 's control of the market . Despite this , ORG expressed criticism concerning the regulation of funerals in GPE . It was , in particular , critical of the fact that , due to a legal vacuum , the DATE Cemetery and Funeral Act , adopted under the previous regime , was still in force . This Act did not distinguish between funerals and cemetery services . Consequently , funerals and cemetery services were automatically considered public utilities on the basis of section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW . ORG further noted that funerals , which could not have been provided freely and privately under the previous regime , had in fact been carried out by registered private enterprises since the independence of GPE and the transition of the economic system . These private enterprises had provided all services except those concerning cemeteries .

CARDINAL . ORG then listed the funeral products and services which should continue to be provided by private funeral enterprises . They included , inter alia , the sale of funeral articles ( coffins , upholstery , cremation urns and memorials ) , funeral flower arrangements , transport of remains ( except for emergency services which should be provided through concession ) , preparing obituary notices , obtaining the necessary permits and documents , organising ceremonies and graveside services , and the sale and installation of tombstones and memorials .

CARDINAL . ORG was of the opinion that the listed services should undoubtedly be subject to a free market regime and that the restrictions in question could not be justified on ethical , health or sanitary or hygiene grounds .

CARDINAL . P. lodged a new complaint in DATE , claiming that the municipal enterprise had acted in a discriminatory manner when it refused to bury the remains transported by him while allowing the remains to be transported by some other private entrepreneurs . Further to the remittal of the case by ORG , ORG issued a final decision on CARDINAL DATE . It found that while it was true that ORG had suffered damage due to the municipal enterprise 's acts , the municipal enterprise had a lawful monopoly on the territory of the respective municipality , which included the transport of remains . It has therefore protected its position by preventing PERSON from carrying out business which he could not have done lawfully . The other entrepreneurs who were allowed to bring remains to the cemetery were from other municipalities . As obiter dictum , ORG again questioned the appropriateness and constitutionality of the system , which should operate only as a transitional measure .

CARDINAL . According to the information available to the ORG from a number of member GPE , in most of them funeral services are subject to the free market and provided by private firms . In some countries public bodies may choose to provide funeral services , however if they do they must compete with private enterprises . For example , in GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE , funeral services may also be provided by public bodies . If so , they are subject to market regulations and must compete on the free market with private enterprises . On the other hand , in GPE , as in GPE , funeral services are listed as public utilities and are mostly provided by public bodies .

CARDINAL . As far as can be seen , funeral services providers are regulated by law in some countries , as is the case in GPE , GPE , GPE or GPE , and unregulated or self - regulated in others , like GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE .

CARDINAL . In GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE , for example , private funeral service providers may only operate with a licence or concession from a public body . Permits or licences are granted by local authorities and subject to a number of requirements , such as professional qualifications and competence , fulfilment of technical , security and health protection standards , and analysis of the company 's financial situation .

CARDINAL . Unlike funerals , it would appear that cemetery and crematorium services are generally provided by public bodies , mostly the municipalities , since they are considered essential public services which are intrinsically linked to public health issues . When crematoria were nationalised in GPE , a transitional period was provided and a certain form of compensation was paid to the private enterprises which had formerly run the country 's crematoria .
